  • Physics in Phyco (Tutorial)

Physics in Phyco (Tutorial)Â¶

Currently Phyco development is focused on dynamics and is able to offer a flexible physics simulation now. But there’s still a few thing you need to know in advance.

To start a simulation you need to create a sim, for example: create sim s. But this simply won’t work because creating sim requires at least one obj (this is the real object in physics).

So the right way to start your simulation is to firstly create your object then simulation

create obj a
create sim s [a]
start s 1

For your convinience, Phyco can automatically separate statements by semicolon. The above code is equivalent to create obj a;create sim s [a];start s 1.

The above code runs without exceptions, but returns you lots of zeroes. Let’s just dive into what actually it does.

create obj a creates an object called “a”. This is the minimum format of create, since no parameter is provided. Then you may wonder if “a” has mass. Sure it has, unless you append mass=0 (though it may cause problems later). Why? There’s default values given in On Specific Class, and that gives mass=1. You may also get why it doesn’t move.

The next command constructs a sim called “s” with objects [a] which you’ve just created. You’re supposed to know that every sim must consists at least one object and objects must be in list (that is, be contained in a pair of brackets []).

The last line starts the sim called “s”. As physics supposed, nothing moves, and Phyco gives you a lot of 0.

Anyway, moving objects is what makes a Physics Engine solid and easily you can make your things move. There’re several ways to make them move. Physically, you can move a object if you give it force, of any type, if at rest:

create sim s [a] field={field(*[0,-g,0])}.

This indeed looks complex, but really not that much. Let’s examine it part by part. The first few words create sim s [a] is exactly same as before, which construct a sim for you. The next block you have an parameter passed to create called field defined.
